questions.question: 1. What is the therapeutic index (TI)?
options: A ratio of toxic dose to effective dose

questions.question: 2. How is the therapeutic index calculated?
3. A lower therapeutic index indicates:
4. A higher therapeutic index suggests:
options: A drug has a wider margin of safety

questions.question: 5. What is tolerance in pharmacodynamics?
options: An increased response to a drug over time
A decreased responsiveness to a drug with repeated use
An allergic reaction to a drug
A genetic predisposition to drug effects

questions.question: 6. What is tachyphylaxis?
options: An acute, rapid onset of tolerance

questions.question: 7. What is idiosyncrasy in drug response?
options: An abnormal or unexpected reaction due to genetic factors

questions.question: 8. What does drug hypersensitivity refer to?
options: An exaggerated immune-mediated response to a drug

questions.question: 9. In pharmacology, what does cumulation refer to?
options: Accumulation of a drug in the body due to administration rate exceeding elimination

questions.question: 10. Why are newborn infants more susceptible to drug effects?
options: They have fully developed liver enzymes
They have underdeveloped hepatic and renal function
They have higher plasma protein levels

questions.question: 11. In elderly patients, drug dosing should be adjusted because:
options: They have impaired detoxification and excretion
They have increased plasma protein binding
They are less sensitive to drugs

questions.question: 12. Why might female patients require lower doses than male patients?
options: Due to differences in body composition and hormonal effects on drug metabolism
Because they have faster drug clearance

questions.question: 13. How does the route of administration affect drug action?
options: It does not affect drug action
It influences the rate and extent of drug absorption

questions.question: 14. What impact does time of administration have on drug action?
options: It can affect drug absorption and side effects
It only affects the therapeutic index

questions.question: 15. Pathological states can alter drug action by:
options: Having no effect on drug action

questions.question: 16. Which of the following does NOT typically affect drug action?
17. What is drug dependence?
options: A physical and/or psychological reliance on a drug

questions.question: 18. How does habituation differ from addiction?
options: Habituation is physical dependence, while addiction is solely psychological
Habituation is a mild dependence, whereas addiction involves severe withdrawal symptoms
Addiction is reversible, habituation is not

questions.question: 19. What is drug interaction?
options: The effect of one drug on the metabolism or action of another

questions.question: 20. Which of the following is an example of an additive drug interaction?
options: Two drugs that produce a combined effect equal to the sum of their individual effects
One drug enhancing the effect of another beyond their individual effects
One drug blocking the effect of another
Two drugs causing an antagonistic effect

questions.question: 21. What is synergism in drug interactions?
options: When two drugs produce an effect equal to their individual effects
When two drugs produce a combined effect greater than the sum of their individual effects
When one drug negates the effect of another
When two drugs have no interaction

questions.question: 22. What does potentiation mean in pharmacology?
options: When one drug increases the effect of another without having an effect on its own
When two drugs cancel each other out
When a drug enhances its own metabolism

questions.question: 23. What is antagonism in drug interactions?
options: When one drug enhances the effect of another
When one drug inhibits or blocks the effect of another

questions.question: 24. What does LD50 represent?
options: The effective dose in 50% of subjects
The lethal dose in 50% of subjects
The dose that produces 50% of the maximal effect
The dose required for half-maximal receptor occupancy

questions.question: 25. What does ED50 represent?
options: The lethal dose for 50% of subjects
The effective dose for 50% of subjects

questions.question: 26. How does enzyme induction affect drug tolerance?
options: It increases drug metabolism, leading to reduced drug levels

questions.question: 27. Which of the following is a mechanism contributing to acquired tolerance?
28. What is cross-tolerance?
options: Tolerance to a drug that also confers tolerance to a related drug
Tolerance that occurs only in the elderly
Tolerance that is due to genetic factors

questions.question: 29. Which factor can lead to increased drug metabolism?
30. How does decreased plasma protein levels affect drug action?
options: It increases the free (active) fraction of a drug
It has no effect on drug action

questions.question: 31. Newborns are more susceptible to drugs because:
options: They have fully matured detoxification systems
They have underdeveloped hepatic and renal functions
They have a lower body water content

questions.question: 32. How can genetic abnormalities affect drug response?
options: They can lead to unpredictable or exaggerated responses
They always result in drug tolerance

questions.question: 33. Which drug is commonly associated with hypersensitivity reactions?
34. Drug cumulation occurs when:
options: The rate of administration exceeds the rate of metabolism and excretion
The drug is taken with food

questions.question: 35. Drug dependence can result in:
options: Severe withdrawal symptoms upon abrupt discontinuation

questions.question: 36. How can emotional factors affect drug action?
options: They do not affect drug action
They can alter the perceived effect of the drug
They determine the drug's therapeutic index

questions.question: 37. Which of the following factors does NOT affect drug action?
38. What is the significance of drug interactions in pharmacotherapy?
options: They can alter the efficacy and safety of drugs

questions.question: 39. Tolerance develops over time primarily due to:
options: Adaptation at the receptor level and increased drug metabolism

questions.question: 40. Which statement best summarizes factors affecting drug action?
options: Drug action is influenced by dose, route, timing, patient characteristics, and interactions
Drug action is solely determined by the chemical structure
